Authors: Poh Kheng Ng, Phaik-Eem Lim, Siew-Moi Phang, Aki Kato
Title:
Molecular assignation of a Malaysian parasite growing on
Gracilaria salicornia as a morphotype of Congracilaria babae
(Gracilariaceae, Rhodophyta)
Keywords:
cox1; Congracilaria babae; Gracilaria salicornia; ITS
region; LSU rRNA; rbcL; red algal parasites
Abstract:
Congracilaria babae and another morphologically similar
parasitic taxon from Malaysia which are found on the common host species
Gracilaria salicornia, differed by the indistinct separation of host and
parasite, presence of short stalk and bisporangia in the former, rather
than the presence of a border of small cells between the parasite and
host, tetrasporangia and absence of stalk in the latter. Phylogenetic
study for the two parasitic taxa based on nuclear, plastidial and
mitochondrial molecular markers was conducted. The Japanese and
Malaysian parasites were placed in the same cluster in nuclear phylogeny
inferred from the ITS region, supporting the monophyly of these
parasites despite the slight anatomical variations observed. In addition
to molecular analyses, morphological and reproductive features including
the lack of rhizoids, similar coloration to hosts, and presence of deep
spermatangial conceptacles shared among the Japanese and Malaysian
parasites supported their inclusion into C. babae. Phylogenetic analyses
on ITS sequences indicated that C. babae most probably had directly
evolved from its current host species G. salicornia. C. babae was shown
to be a member of Gracilaria sensu stricto along with its host. C. babae
growing on G. salicornia is characterized by the having plastidial and
mitochondrial DNA identical to its host, while retaining its unique
nuclear identity.
